newsitem.title: USA: Key IMM currency futures end moderately lower.
newsitem.headline: Key IMM currency futures end moderately lower.

text.p: Key IMM currency futures ended moderately lower after a session of steady losses.
September yen futures erased all of Tuesday's gains and broke through several support levels and September marks ended not far from contract lows.
The dollar, stocks and bonds were strong all session.
"It was steady pressure all day and they closed the dollar toward its highs," an IMM currency analyst said. "We've got a big week next week and alot of volatility ahead of us."
Traders said all eyes were now on next week's heavy U.S. economic calendar.

The Federal Open Market Committee meets July 1 and 2, national purchasing management and June jobs data will be released, and trade will shut early Thursday and be closed Friday for U.S Independence Day.
Traders said action was only light to moderate Friday.
Currency weakness began overnight and continued all session, further hampered by U.S. data this morning.

The dollar gleaned added strength from the U.S. final first-quarter gross domestic product, revised to up 5.9 percent from the latest preliminary reading of 5.8 percent. A Reuters poll had pegged an average forecast of up 5.9 percent.
The overnight moves got started when yen took a hit on dampened expectations for a rate rise in Japan. Concerns over a soft common European currency plagued marks and Swiss, traders said.
Day session trade just extended those moves, traders said.
"It really wasn't a very dramatic day, despite the price action," an IMM currency trader said. "I trickled lower all day but it wasn't great volume and it wasn't poor volume," he said.
He noted bank buying late in the day in September marks at $0.5780, stemming losses.
Marks slid to $0.5780 during the session, not far from the $0.5770 contract low set June 6.

At the close, Sept yen was off $0.000101 to $0.008827, marks were off $0.0044 to $0.5782, Swiss francs fell $0.0084 to $0.6941, sterling fell $0.0018 to $1.6596, Canadian dollars rose $0.0010 to $0.7282 and Mexican pesos were $0.000100 higher at $0.121650. ((Derivatives desk 312-408-8750))
